description: A festival celebrating the health and happiness of girls, featuring the display of ornamental dolls.
A festival where people dress as demons and participate in various activities to ward off evil spirits.

Every year about one million people visit the city for the festival. Kairakuen in Mito was a landscape gardening project started by Nariaki Tokugawa. The park opened in July 1842. In early spring, about 100 different types of 3,000 plum trees put flowers, making Kairakuen one of the three most famous parks of Japan.

Doll Festival - Festival for Girls. Nearly 1,000 years ago, there was a custom as a seasonal event, children's dolls are specially displayed in the home, and games played, stories told and a feast given.
1,200 traditional Hina Dolls are placed on the 60 steps of the Toomisaki Shrine in Katsuura City, Chiba Prefecture. 25,000 hina dolls sent from all over Japan decorate the entire city.

festival_name: Memorial Service for the Victims of Great Tokyo Air Raids
description: A memorial service held to commemorate the victims of the Great Tokyo Air Raids during World War II.
Cherry Blossoms Festival along the Riverbank of the Sumida River, Mukojima, Sumida-ku. The Mukojima geishas serve tea to cherry blossom viewers on weekends.
Ueno Park is probably the most well known cherry blossom viewing spot in Tokyo and it is most crowded.
Yasukuni Shrine offers entertainments for its sakura festival during the period.
Children's kabuki is played at many places in Japan and its history is long. Many teams selected from around the Kanto district join this event.
Lanterns will be decorated along the Meguro River for two weeks from the day Tokyo Meteorological Agency announces the opening of Sakura in Tokyo.
Along and over the Tsuruuda River, numerous carp streamers are flown to wish for good growth for boys.
